text:
Hello <@U010EDFHFGU> - Great idea.
Yes I have seen some companies in America using similar raw material to make hand sanitizers.

I am going to ask you to lead the effort of identifying exactly what the raw materials are so we can propose this to the right people.
Do you need me to recruit folks to help you with this?

text:
Hi, I similarly want to resurrect an earlier thread here about the safety of DIY masks. For healthcare workers, cloth is not enough. There needs to be some kind of filter--even if it is not the N95 filter.

Additionally, the mask has to seal to your face, which is why N95 masks are more structured than cloth masks. This is so air only goes through the filter and not around and into gaps in your mask.

There is a local makerspace near my workplace (containing many of my colleagues) that is having their 3D-printed masks tested by a local hospital. They are still waiting for validation from the hospital, but I believe their method may work in an emergency, and I can report back on whether the test was successful. If it is successful, then I believe this is one of few DIY designs that may work.

Their instructions are here: <https://lowellmakes.com/covid-19-response/> They're using furnace filter material instead.

Anyone currently working on mask manufacturing in ET?

attachments.title: COVID-19 Response
attachments.text: A note on safety: We are collaborating with healthcare professionals and other makers to develop open-source personal protective equipment; however, we caution that these items have not been tested…

elements.text:
Hi, I similarly want to resurrect an earlier thread here about the safety of DIY masks. For healthcare workers, cloth is not enough. There needs to be some kind of filter--even if it is not the N95 filter.

Additionally, the mask has to seal to your face, which is why N95 masks are more structured than cloth masks. This is so air only goes through the filter and not around and into gaps in your mask.

There is a local makerspace near my workplace (containing many of my colleagues) that is having their 3D-printed masks tested by a local hospital. They are still waiting for validation from the hospital, but I believe their method may work in an emergency, and I can report back on whether the test was successful. If it is successful, then I believe this is one of few DIY designs that may work.

Their instructions are here:

They're using furnace filter material instead.

Anyone currently working on mask manufacturing in ET?

text:
I'd also like to add that N95 is not a "thing", but a testing standard. The materials can be different across masks. All N95 means is that it met the U.S. agency for PPE equipment's test standard. There are a lot of details about this standard on the CDC website: <https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/96-101/default.html>

The general idea is that both saline solution and salt particles are sprayed at the mask to test the filter. If the filter blocks 95% of those particles, it's N95. The "N" is for non-oily particles, since oil presents different challenges. For COVID-19, it may be possible to get by with a lower standard mask + a face shield in the event of shortages. At least, a mask that directs airflow horizontally + a face shield that would block most spray from patients could work.

idk if that's helpful, but hoped (as a mech e/real things person lol) this information would be useful to someone!

elements.text: I'd also like to add that N95 is not a "thing", but a testing standard. The materials can be different across masks. All N95 means is that it met the U.S. agency for PPE equipment's test standard. There are a lot of details about this standard on the CDC website:

The general idea is that both saline solution and salt particles are sprayed at the mask to test the filter. If the filter blocks 95% of those particles, it's N95. The "N" is for non-oily particles, since oil presents different challenges. For COVID-19, it may be possible to get by with a lower standard mask + a face shield in the event of shortages. At least, a mask that directs airflow horizontally + a face shield that would block most spray from patients could work.

idk if that's helpful, but hoped (as a mech e/real things person lol) this information would be useful to someone!

text: Hey <@U010NBXJN06>, This great info!  I had come across several 3D printed DIY masks, but I am skeptical of Ethiopia's capacity to mass produce masks via 3D printing. But, yes we should organize all ideas for the face masks by category i.e. 3D printed, sewed, no-sewing ..  and so on excel doc

elements.text: , This great info!  I had come across several 3D printed DIY masks, but I am skeptical of Ethiopia's capacity to mass produce masks via 3D printing. But, yes we should organize all ideas for the face masks by category i.e. 3D printed, sewed, no-sewing ..  and so on excel doc

text: Thanks! I think this could definitely be produced with other methods--the point is more that the mask needs to be rigid and seal to the face, it cannot be loose or soft like cloth. Will continue to look for other methods...
